In partnership.

Good evening Bulldog families!

The long awaited announcement of how schools will re-open was delivered today. Governor Cooper announced that all public schools in North Carolina will re-open this fall under Plan B, which is a combination of in-person and online learning for every student. This plan will allow Brevard Academy, as well as surrounding schools, flexibility to choose more restrictive measures, as necessary.

We have been working diligently on plans for each of the three options laid before us earlier this summer. Now that we have received guidance from the governor, we will begin solidifying plans to safely begin the school year this fall. As always, our top priority is the safety of our staff, students, and families.

We will make an official statement with the processes and procedures once they are approved. Please remember we are holding weekly Q&A’s via Facebook live and will be rolling out info as it is made available. As always, thank you for your time, patience, and support.

#ILoveBA #BulldogStrong

Attention Free/Reduced Lunch Parents:

TODAY - Monday, May 4th is the deadline for the Emergency Meals To Go Program sign up:

Visit - https://NCmealstoyou.formstack.com/forms/apply

Select Transylvania County as the 'District' and type in Brevard Academy as the 'School/Campus'

If your child does not know their student ID you may email Mrs. Best at kbest@brevardacademy.school or simply enter a "0" in this box.

After you sign up you'll get an emergency meals-to-you Box delivered to your home for each child under 18 every other week. Each Box will include 10 kid friendly breakfasts and 10 kid-friendly lunches!

Two meals per day for each kid for 2 weeks. All foods are shelf stable which means they will be good for a long time period.

Your child. Our Mission.

Ted Duncan

Today, at the Friday assembly, the Intramural class performed a traditional Philippine folk dance called Tinikling. The dance involves two people beating, tapping, and sliding bamboo poles on the ground and against each other in coordination with one or more dancers who step over and in between the poles in a dance.

These kiddos, who had never been exposed to this dance before, spent 2 hours a week for three weeks, practicing and....well, just see for yourself!

Nailed it!!

If the weather changes and we need to adjust the schedule again, I will call you and update local media as well as our webpage and Facebook with all necessary information.

Best,

Ted Duncan

One of the super cool things we introduced to our BA family this year, is two water bottle filling stations. We recognize the abundance of harmful ways plastic water bottles are impacting our environment and want to do our part.

Americans buy 29 billion water bottles a year. For every six bottles people buy, only one is recycled. That leads to a big problem given the fact that water bottles do not biodegrade, but rather photodegrade. This means that it takes at least up to 1,000 years for every single bottle to decompose, leaking pollutants into our soil and water along the way. Yuck!

Toss your plastic bottled water habit for good! A cultural shift can change the way plastic water bottles affect our environment.
Since the school year began, your Brevard Academy Bulldogs have helped eliminate waste from 5,449 disposable plastic bottles!!!!

Way to go Bulldogs!

#ILoveBA #BulldogLife #RecycleReduceReuse #PlaticWaterBottles

Happy Veterans Day!

Do you know how Veterans Day came about?

The short version is:

In 1938, Armistice Day was passed, as a day earmarked to honor the end of World War I and the veterans who served, which officially took place on November 11, 1918.

With the end of World War II and the Korean War, it became necessary to amend the Act of 1938 to include American veterans of ALL wars.With that, the name “Armistice” was changed to “Veterans”, as it remains today.

To all our Veterans, our current servicemen and women, we want to thank you for your service!!

#ILoveBA #BulldogLife #VeteransDay

Election day comes every year, between the 2nd and the 8th of November. It is statutorily set as “the Tuesday next after the first Monday in the month of November” or “the first Tuesday after November 1”.

Ever wonder how dates like this were selected?

Well, for election day in particular, the weather and farming dictated when elections were held. In the 1800s, the agrarian economy was an important factor. In fact, farming was the occupation of 69 percent of working Americans and farmers weren’t able to travel easily until the harvest was over. Also, the onset of winter conditions in some areas made travel a problem, so elections happened in the late fall.

And now you know!

#ILoveBA #BulldogLife #ElectionDay #KnowledgeIsPower
